advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD. </strong></font><br><blockquote>The red part shows all the IBM-PC software boxes the VP could run.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Intelligence is in the game"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #4 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Circa September, 1982. This is likely one of the final Commodore advertisements for the VIC-20, as the C64 was soon to be launched.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGAWORLD PREVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Exorset was designed by Motorola firstly to be a development kit for the MC6809 and Motorola systems.
It has a built-in green 9'' monochrom screen and two 5''1/4 floppy-drives. It runs under XDOS (a compatible MDOS operating system).
It is sold with a compiled Basic (BASICM), a text editor and an assembler.
Douro reports us : The Motorola Exorset-30 has amazing graphic and sound capability. A modified version of this hardware is used in Williams arcade machines !
computer.name: EXORSET 30
